text: my name is Joe Franti and I am a developer Advocate currently unemployed
but soon to be employed at a new place so uh news in two weeks uh you can get
me at this is Joe Frank on all of the socials whatever socials that we're using these days uh and today I'm going
to talk to you about the importance of developer experience and how we can
influence developer experience and how the choices that we make when we're writing code can change how other
developers feel about the code that we're writing so let's start with a story to illustrate this and this is
something that many of you may have experienced in your developer lives so you are a software developer
you've been tasked with integrating a new developer tool so let's call this tool kod magig and
someone at your work told you that kod magig is recommended for its Advanced
features and its timesaving capabilities and you're excited about the potential
that this offers so you Embark upon the Journey of onboarding with Cod magic and you start with the obvious you open up
your favorite search engine you try and find some online tutorials some documentation to try and understand the
basic concept and the functionalities of cod magig but you quickly realize that there's not many online learning
resources available and the ones that are are quite poorly written they're poorly structured the official
documentation is not only incomplete but some of it is out of date it lacks clear
examples it doesn't have practical use cases and you do find some tutorials but
they're either really simple basic things or they're overly complex and
they leave out steps and they leave you feeling frustrated so you're determined to
overcome this setback you reach out to the Cod of magig community to see if they can give you any assistance you
join their online Forum you join their Discord hoping to find guidance from
more experienced users but unfortunately the community turns out to be quite
unresponsive they're unwelcoming to newcomers and your questions just go unanswered for
weeks but you are a consumer Prof professional so you decide that you're going to just dive in and start
experimenting with code magic yourself and you're going to create a small project but you discovered that the tool
has a very steep learning curve it's got a complex uh code base that lacks
structure it's challenging to navigate and it's difficult to even find out what the features are of this tool it lacks
proper error handling it doesn't have good test coverage you're getting cryptic error messages that don't
actually help you with troubleshooting you find numerous bugs and inconsistencies and you attempt to
report these to the kod magig community but their response is so slow and they never actually respond to any of the
issues that you raise and your the weeks turn into months your enthusiasm for
learning kod of magig wains and you begin to question your colleagues about why they chose this tool in the first
place and this whole experience the lack of learning resources the unhelpful
community the inherent flaws in the tool itself have all made for this frustrating and
demoralizing experience and you realize that despite promising all these
features Kama jig has such a poor user experience such a lack of support and it
technical issues make it just impossible to use ultimately you and your team decide that you're not going to use it
you abandon it in favor of other tools that have better documentation and more supportive community and a much
shallower learning curve and this is what developer experience is all about
having a poor developer experience has cost kod magig a customer it has ruined
their reputation in your eyes all because they have this bad developer
experience and I'm sure many of you have had similar if perhaps less extreme
experiences in your Journeys as recoding and this first experience that you have with a tool or a framework or a language
is essential to developers deciding whether or not they want to continue to use the code that you've written and it
will sway the way developers perceive the quality of the code that you've written uh and the quality of the code
within your organization so developer experience or devx as it's often called uh or DX
describes the journey that a developer takes as they on board with your code as
they write with your tools as they on board with your teams and it's the lived
experience of developers and the points of friction that they encounter in their everyday work and so what I would like
to talk to you about today is the different points that Encompass developer
experience uh how we can uh improve developer experience and then I'm going
to go into some actual technical examples of things that I've seen that I think improve developer
experience and developer experience isn't just that getting started phase it runs all the way through your work so
while you're developing with your choice of tooling While You're Building while you're testing while you're debugging
while you're releasing and as people who are building tools and Frameworks and libraries even
if we do manage to make the sale and we get people to on board with the things that we're writing we have to have a
pleasant developer experience as they're using it to keep them in the future otherwise developers are just going to
jump jump to a different tool that has a better developer experience they're going to abandon the things that we're
making poor developer experience will cost us money it'll ruin our customer base and it can damage our
reputation and a common misconception is that developer experience only affects the tools and the products themselves
but it has such a massive human factor as well things like having clear goals
or feeling psychologically safe when you're using a tool not feeling belittled feeling like you are capable
can have a massive impact on how a developer feels about the code that you're writing and improving devx can
also have a huge impact on things like productivity on satisfaction on
engagement and even on employee retention so let's take a deeper dive
into what can actually affect developer experience there was a brilliant paper
that was released recently by the Association for Computing Machinery um I put a link down there and I will share
these slides out at the end and it breaks developer experience into these three segments so we have Flow State we
have cognitive load and we have feedback loops and when we consider all of these three things together they can describe
the full range of frictions that developers experience as they're working with our code bases so we're going to
take a brief look into each of these three and then go on to some more practical examples
as I'm sure we are all aware and has been mentioned in a few talks already software development can be quite
difficult it's complex it's complicated there's always new things to be learning
new languages new methodologies new Frameworks and reading and writing and
learning code all contribute to what you can consider a workload on your brain so
we call this a cognitive load and cognitive load refers to how much information your brain needs in order to
process and complete a task and that is alongside all the other
stuff that your brain is doing so thinking about what you're having for lunch thinking about what temperature
you're sitting in how much noise is going on in the background cognitive load is how much effort it takes for you
to learn something and not only learn it then retain that information for later use and psychologists refer to this
thing called working memory which is how much capacity your brain has to uh hold
information temporarily and it works really similar to how the Ram in your computer works so you have a certain
amount of this fast access storage available to you and as you're doing tasks as you're learning things as
you're writing code as you're reading things you're filling up this fast access storage and every time you pick
up a new task you're putting a new thing in in there and eventually you will run out of available space and you will need
to stop doing one task in order to start doing another task or you're going to find yourself slowing down you're going
to find yourself making mistakes and you're going to find things more difficult and cognitive load can
increase if you're working on a more difficult or a more complex thing or if
you're trying to understand something new but it can also as I mentioned be increased by extraneous uh information
that's being presented while you're working so if you're working in a noisy environment or if there's a large level
of light or not enough light or uh things like context switching so
you're reading documentation and maybe you can't find the thing that you're looking for and you have to open up a
browser so you've then got you know a few different Windows of things open in that context switching means you're
running a bunch of different tasks you are filling up that memory and even things like feeling tired can reduce
your uh cognitive capacity uh feeling bored or feeling anxious can they will
all decrease the working memory that you have and thus decrease your cognitive load
capacity is that beat coming for us or is okay we will uh assume that came from
outside when cognitive load is high developers are going to need to devote more time and more effort to learning
something to completing a task and they're going to be more likely to make mistakes and less likely to be
Innovative which is kind of interesting so to improve developer experience team
should be aiming to reduce cognitive load as much as possible and we should be looking for ways to eliminate things
like task switching eliminate unnecessary hurdles in the development process so we should
be doing things like creating well organized code bases creating upto-date
well structured documentation uh we should be making sure that we are setting well-defined
tasks for developers with clear objectives so that they can onboard easily into our projects and we can have
entire dedicated devx teams who can work towards self-service tools to help
developers to streamline the steps required for developers to onboard to to
release uh to debug um there's like there's a whole
area of things that we can look into here uh we should be considering things
like presenting information in different styles uh so allowing people to learn through the
the method that works best for them so are they visual Learners would they rather dive straight into a code example
would they rather have a step-by-step tutorial allow developers to to use the tools that best Aid them uh for their
own cognition because when our cognitive load is well balanced we find it much
easier to be efficient and to be productive and it allows for this thing
called Flow State to happen and I'm sure you've all felt it before or you've heard somebody say you know I'm in the
zone when I'm programming like I'm really focused on that thing or people have said like my flow was interrupted
because I've got too many emails or too many meetings today and this idea of being in the zone is
Flow State and it's a mental disposition in which a person becomes fully immersed
in the activity that they're performing it's actually quite an enjoyable feeling
uh when you're in the zone you are more creative you are more Innovative you
feel more motivated and you will find yourself being more efficient and when you're in that flow
State learning actually becomes much easier and you will find self retaining information much easier and it can make
things like repetitive tasks actually feel quite gratifying and this can cause us to
perform better as developers produce higher quality products have better
Innovation generally so it stands for reason that we want to try and create an environment where developers can
maintain this Flow State so in order to do this there's a few different things we can do firstly
the most important thing is you want to make sure that challenge and skill level required to complete that challenge are
well balanced so tasks should prevent present enough challenge that the mind
is engaged and learning but not confused or frustrated too much challenge can
leave the developer feeling helpless leave you feeling foolish like you can't complete a task and on the other end of
the spectrum tasks that are too simple can leave you feeling babied bored and
belittled I remember once my dad called me uh and he said you know my computer
is broken and I was like why don't you just look up how to fix it there's this
thing called Google you know uh and his response kind of surprised me he he said
you know I can look up how to fix this thing on Google and I can spend two hours
trying to find an answer to why my computer is broken and after 2 hours I still won't be certain that I have found
the fix I don't know what I I don't have enough skill to reach this challenge
whereas I can call you you can look up why my computer is broken and you will probably understand within the two hours
why it's broken and you will have a fix there is a certainty there your skill level is matched to this challenge but
because his skill level was so unbalanced with this challenge he just gave up before he'd even started so we
need to make sure when we're building experiences for developers that we are considering the skill level that they
have and what challenges we're presenting them with and make sure that we're catering
accordingly we want to create a confidence in developers that if a task is unexpectedly complicated we are going
to be able to handhold them through it and they are going to get there in the end and getting this balance of
Challenge and skill right is what allows to developers develop to feel like they are in control of the process and that
they are picking the right tools and clearly defining tasks and
setting achievable goals can really help with this uh completing tasks allows developers to feel a sense of
achievement you we all love it when you tick things off your to-do list it helps
you want to do the next thing and the next thing and pick up the next challenge and it helps you stay in Flow
State and removes the chance of boredom and conversely things like interruptions
distractions and delays will all hinder your Flow State and anytime you struggle
to find information that you need or have too many tasks that you need to do at the same time you're going to be
pushed right out of that flow state so if you're constantly being pinged or
distracted in an office for example or if you have to toggle between too many pages to read
documentation it's like imagine a runner on on a track every time they have to do
a new task or every time they are distracted it's you putting a brick out in front of that Runner and the runner
is going to trip over and then they have to get back up again and start running again and that takes more energy and
every brick that you're putting out in front of that Runner it's going to take them more energy to pick up and they may
just give up switching between tasks getting lost
or frustrated or distracted while you're searching for information cannot only
you know knock you out of Flow State but it can also make you feel anxious it can make you feel frustrated and that's
going to reduce your cognitive load increase your cognitive load
sorry and Flow State depends on developers having the autonomy and the opportunity to work on challenges that
are uh that they find fulfilling and the best way to find out whether you've got the balance right so whether the
developers are feeling like their skill level matches is to get feedback from
them which brings us nicely on to feedback loops so it feels like a really
obvious thing to say but sustaining meaningful feedback loops between developer effort and uh and the impact
that they're having is Central to creating a good developer experience how
can we know that we're doing a good job at creating a good developer experience if we're not asking developers whether
they're enjoying the experience feedback allows us to spot mistakes it
allows us to learn and improve but it also Fosters a feeling of visibility within our communities so if you're
looking to improve your developer experience you should be aiming to have as short a feedback loop as possible
it's imperative that you make giving feedback really easy for developers so
that they feel like they can talk to you but it's also important that you action the feedback that they give so that they
feel like you're actually listening to them and doing so will allow you to discover where developers are struggling
in your processes where you've accidentally placed those bricks out in front of them and they're tripping over
and it'll ultimately lead to you building more beloved products and similarly we should be
looking to provide feedback to developers as they use our products we should be getting feedback to them nice
and quickly as they work so that we can keep them in that flow State and let them know that they're on the right
track and keep them motivated so things like having great test coverage in
things that we're writing allows developers to know when they've made a mistake change it immediately move on to
the next thing we should be enabling continuous integration so that they can run the tests while they're working and
get feedback immediately we should be offering nice clear steps in our
onboarding things like how do I install dependencies how do I get started how do I run this project what do I do when I
want to build this next thing give me nice step-by-step tutorials with a clear
indication that I have succeeded so that I can know that I'm doing the right thing that I'm on boarding in the right
way providing slow feedback can leave developers in the dark or it can
interrupt them midf flow and obviously no feedback is just not helping them at
all and feedback itself could be feedback is an entire talk in itself
really um and I've put a link here to an excellent article by Tim Cochran uh the
technical director of thoughtworks who's written an entire article on feedback loops how to implement them how to
measure them I highly recommend reading that blog post so the next thing to talk about
when we talk about developer experience is measurement and the Eternal question for developer experience is how on Earth
do I measure this how do I know whether the changes that I'm making are having a
positive impact or a negative one and DX encompasses so many different aspects it
is it's challenging to quantify but here are a few common things that you can
measure so firstly as I mentioned get feedback from your developers so it can
be as simple as conducting a survey asking for a little feedback at the end of a tutorial um and get suggestions
directly from them about where they stumbled where you can improve we can use things like net promoter score to
tell us whether or not our customers like our products whether they would recommend us there's also customer
satisfaction score which lets you know at the point of Sal so at the point at which the developer decided Yep this is
the product for me why did they decide that what was it about your tool or your product or your library that made them
want to use it and these can help you sort of gauge overall satisfaction and
you should be tracking this within your internal teams as well so I'm not just talking about the external products that
we're putting out but you should be doing regular check-ins with people that you're working with about where they
think improvements could be made in your flow uh in your Internal Documentation
and track things like as sad as it is to say track things like employee turnover
you can get absolutely Vital Information at Exit interviews about where in your
process things are broken and where you can improve things for developers who are going to come in the
future then we can look at things like code quality metrics so we've got code review feedback code complexity code
coverage uh how many bugs are being worked on over what period of Time how
many issues are reported on GitHub you can track these metrics over time and
then see how they're changing and see whether the changes that you are making so documentation improvements more
tutorials more demos whether those are making the impact that you want to see
um make sure you're also checking documentation quality so uh is your
documentation accessible are you including code Snippets are you including full working
examples um is it all up to date have you included different ways of working
so have we got a videoos as well as maybe written and regularly check trim out
anything that is out of date or that is misleading or that is confusing
people then we've got things like kpis we've got our burndown charts our curn
boards number of completed story points the more we improve internal developer

on how you can assess the effectiveness of the communication Within in your team

and the overarching goal of developer experience is to provide a smooth and
efficient and pleasant experience for developers and I tend to think of DX as

Basics there are some standard hygiene practices that might seem really obvious

you're being what you're actually doing is you're raising the barrier to entry because you're you're placing that brick

boarding by making use of Dev containers or code spaces and if you've not used

developer that you might never ever get to meet or talk to or explain your intentions to it helps users to quickly

uh outline guidelines for how I can contribute to the project so how how

specify any coding styles that you're expecting for PRS any linting rules that you want me to follow any testing
Frameworks or anything else that you want contributors to follow make it as

and mention any restrictions or particular requirements for using
it a well-written read me is going to massively improve the clarity the
usability just the pleasantness of the developer experience of your projects

a huge difference to your read me and maybe it's not a read me maybe you're writing a blog post or maybe you're
writing a tutorial technical writing is a skill in
itself what you're doing is you're breaking down complex Concepts and making them accessible and digestible
and an important component of good technical writing is understanding who you're writing for
so before you even you know put your fingers on that keyboard and start typing consider your audience and get a

role in the company that they're at what do they care about uh what's their
technical expertise what is their responsibilities are they beginners are
they intermediate users are they experts who is it that you're speaking to once
you've identified exactly the audience for the things that you're writing then
you can do something called creating a persona for them um so give create a
fictional person give them a name a background a storyline um for why they have ended up
on your read me and what it is that they want to know and then when you are writing write with them in

then these are more General uh advice so use simple and direct language when
you're writing convey your message as clearly and concisely as possible uh try
and keep a consistent tone of voice a consistent use of tenses and nouns and
points of view I seen so many readmes where it said we are going to do this we are going to do this you are going to do
this I did this and I'm just like who's doing this right nice Lo complexity sentences
don't labor the point try not to repeat yourself use low complexity vocabulary
and keep your paragraphs nice and short um and give frequent examples so if you're telling me to do something also
give me an example of how to do it focus on legibility readability and
accessibility so use headings to break up large blocks of text uh write
descriptive link uh link texts so uh
links should make sense on their own as a standalone as well as in a sentence uh
and of course give your images descriptive alt text use inclusive language when you're
writing um think about ability specific language so instead of saying uh see
this thing say read this thing uh instead of saying look at this thing say
check out this thing uh try not to refer to things as crazy or dumb instead use
wild or baffling um and there's no need for gendered language when you're writing I
hope this is something we've all learned already uh we can swap out words like man hours or work hours that kind of
thing and avoid using idioms or slang these can confuse people who don't speak
the same first language as you um and then finally avoid saying that a
process is easy or simple uh this can make folks who are
confused or who are new to a subject feel like they're being belittled if you say do this in three easy steps and I'm
or I'm stuck on step two I'm like oh God I can't even get through the easy thing there's no way I'm going to be able to
you know use this tool so instead of easy to say do this thing in three steps
I'm like three steps that's not much I can do three steps
I don't know about you but I have a really short attention span and when I see a huge block of text my eyes just

images um code samples anything to illustrate the point that you're trying
to make um and this also helps to engage people who perhaps don't learn best by
reading who want a more visual approach to learning and consider as I said before

about this CL this code and we write it as clearly as we possibly can because as

you're not going to be able to explain your reasoning to them or explain the decisions that you made your explanation
has to be within the code itself so your code should be as unsurprising as possible it should lower the cognitive
load as much as possible and allow developers to stay in that flow State as they're reading you want to think of it
as like picking up your favorite novel and reading through a story to understand what it was that you were
thinking when you were writing this code So to that end these are a few things
that I prefer to see in my projects so firstly uh write pure functions so
functions without side effects that do only one thing they're much easier to read they are solely dependent on
themselves and they won't affect external State they won't do things that will confuse us or surprise us it means
readers have less head compute they have less to keep in that uh
quick access memory uh less to maintain as they're working through the code we're reducing their cognitive
load functions with fewer arguments are generally easier to comprehend while
you're reading code the more arguments you have the more I need to go okay so that's
something I need to remember what's that thing okay that's another thing I need to remember what does that do if you can
refactor your functions to make them smaller and reduce the number of arguments
ments promises are more readable and more intuitive than nested callbacks
they make it easier to follow the linear flow of the code so um you're trying to
understand the instructions of each step um and Promises just result in more
concise code blocks which again are easier to maintain the flow of the logic
in your head uh it just makes it easier to understand the flow of the
asynchronous op operations of the code and again we're aiming to reduce
cognitive load return early and often by replacing
your return statements at the top of your functions at the beginning of your functions or your methods you're
immediately communicating the conditions under which the function should exit which is going to again reduce our
cognitive load if we go through the code and we say oh okay we've got to this point here we exit I don't even need to
read the next bit this is the bit that I'm currently interested in again it's minimizing the need for the developer to
hold multiple conditional branches in their mind as they're reading the code so try and return early and often and
then avoid nested ifs if you can so avoid the Pyramid of Shame uh as your nesting level increases
the code becomes more convoluted it becomes less legible it's much more likely that developer is going to make a
mistake as they're reading it uh they're it's going to be much harder to follow the logic and to understand the
intention behind what you had written um the Pyramid of Shame leads to bugs leads
to maintenance issues and of course again increases cognitive load we making them hold more things in their

abbreviations I know it's nice to abbreviate and have nice neat uh function names but if you describe what
